text: so as you all know the data center
technology data centers have evolved
phenomenal rate over the last few years
certainly technological innovations in
virtualization and cloud has meant that
we've seen an exponential increase in
cloud applications and infrastructures
when I talk to customers I've seen a
subtle change in direction I remember a
few years ago people used to say oh what
can we put in the cloud now there's a
slight change on that it's what can't be
put in the cloud what about your
applications and what about the data
itself
what about safeguarding that and like I
said you know previously people have
thought oh yeah we're just going to
offload everything to our cloud service
provider AWS in this case but is that
the case and so really you know that
cloud service providers people like
Amazon everyone they they talk about
something called shared responsibility
and what what a shared responsibility
actually mean and and and how does it
actually differ with the type of cloud
that you might be engaging in or how
does it actually differ when you've got
a hybrid set all right to give you that
kind of baseline idea of what it does
actually look like you've got a simple
chart here
so you can see on the left hand side
here if you're going to do everything
DIY so on premise you're actually
responsible for everything right you're
responsible for the infrastructure the
hypervisor the middle layer the
applications and the data if you taking
that initial kind of dip into the cloud
you might look at infrastructure as a
service which is most which is what most
people tend to go for those easy to type
workloads and you can see in this
instance you know Amazon will take care
of the infrastructure the kind of
hypervisor in the OS and then as you
kind of turn up the level and you go to
platform as-a-service
if you're looking at things like RDS as
a service for your databases you can see
Amazon are taking more responsibility
for it and then finally when you go
software-as-a-service you've kind of
shelved everything into the cloud but
what you will see and what remains
consistent over this whole model is that
you are responsible for the data not the
cloud service not the cloud service
provider right it's your responsibility
and you see that clean remains
consistent and in that kind of hybrid
setup you can see what the commonality
and the touch points are so when you're
looking at compliance and regulation you
need to take this kind of model into
account to understand where are your
areas of demarcation and what do you
need to kind of put in place
